questions.question: Question 1: Deposition of which of the following is responsible for band-shaped keratopathy?
questions.explanation:
Band-shaped keratopathy is caused by pathological calcium deposition on the cornea in the form 
of a band. On exam, there is a white band-like formation of calcium across the corneal surface with irregular 
borders and a peripheral clearing of cornea between the calcium deposits and the limbus. The 
calcium deposition is typically found beneath the epithelial layer within Bowman’s layer but may 
extend into the anterior stroma. Once the visual axis starts to get involved, there will be progressive loss of vision. Recurrence is 
common unless the predisposing cause is identified and treated. Local causes such as chronic ocular irritation or inflammatory conditions and systemic 
diseases that elevate serum calcium levels are the main causes for band-shaped keratopathy. It 
can rarely have hereditary causes as well. Image given below shows band-shaped keratopathy.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient was with the given finding has been having painless and slowly progressive vision 
loss for the past 10 years. Which of the following diseases is not associated with the given 
condition?
questions.explanation:
167 
Sold by @itachibot Based on the given clinical scenario and ocular finding depicted here, it is suggestive of 
band-shaped keratopathy, and systemic lupus erythematosus is not associated with this 
condition. Band-shaped keratopathy (BSK) is due to calcium deposition, primarily in the form of 
hydroxyapatite, in the epithelial basement membrane, Bowman's layer, and the anterior stroma. 
Initially, these deposits are grey but may become chalky-white as the degeneration progresses. lt typically presents as a band-shaped opacity in the interpalpebral zone with a clear interval 
between the ends of the band and the limbus. The condition begins at the periphery and gradually 
progresses towards the centre. The surface of this opaque band is stippled due to holes in the 
calcium plaques in the area of nerve canals of Bowman's membrane. Causes of band-shaped keratopathy include local causes such as chronic ocular irritation or 
inflammatory conditions and systemic diseases that elevate serum calcium levels: Treatment: • Medical management- Chelation using topical ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) 1.5–3.0% • Surgical management- Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) using excimer laser or manual 
superficial keratectomy Local causes 
Systemic diseases HyperparathyroidismSarcoid 
osisMultiple myelomaHypop 
hosphatemiaPaget diseaseCh 
ronic renal failure Chronic anterior uveitis (espe 
cially inJuvenile Idiopathic A 
rthritis)Interstitial keratitisS 
uperficial keratitisPhthisis bu 
lbiEnd-stage glaucomaSilicon 
e oil left in the aphakic eye

questions.question:
Question 3: 156 
Sold by @itachibot A 64-year-old woman was brought by her son, during a cataract outreach camp. She gives a 
history of trauma to her left eye, one year back and a complete loss of vision in that eye since 
then. Her image is given below. Which of the following statement is true about her condition?

options.a: Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in this lady.
options.b: The given lesion is an adherent leucoma.
options.c: It is due to scars involving Bowman's layer and superficial stroma.
options.d: Excimer laser phototherapeutic keratectomy is the current treatment of choice.

questions.explanation:
The above image shows a dense white opacity, which results from the scarring of more than half 
of the stroma, characteristic of leucoma. Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in patients with corneal opacities, who have lost their 
vision or who do not expect to recover it. It improves cosmetic appearance by altering the white 
colour of the opacity and blending it to normal eye colour. Depending on the density, corneal opacities are graded as nebula, macula and leucoma. • Nebular corneal opacity (fog or mist): • Hard-to-see corneal scar, due to superficial scars involving Bowman's layer and superficial 
stroma. • Slit-lamp detection is required. • A thin, diffuse nebula covering the pupillary area interferes more with vision than the localised 
leucoma away from the pupillary area. Nebula produces more discomfort due to blurred image 
(irregular astigmatism). 168 
Sold by @itachibot • Macular corneal opacity: • Semi-dense opacity that can be seen with proper illumination. • Due to scarring involving about half the corneal stroma. • Leucomatous corneal opacity (leucoma simplex): • White scar that is easily seen just by looking at the eye. • Due to scarring of more than half of the stroma • Adherent leucoma: • It results when healing occurs after perforation of the cornea with incarceration of iris Secondary changes in corneal opacity which may be seen in long-standing cases include hyaline 
degeneration, calcareous degeneration, pigmentation and atheromatous ulceration. Treatment: • Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice in leucomatous corneal opacities. • Optical iridectomy may be performed in cases with central adherent leucomas • Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) performed with excimer laser is useful only in superficial 
(nebular) corneal opacities.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with bilateral corneal 
opacities in a neonate?
questions.explanation:
Keratoglobus is least likely to be associated with bilateral corneal opacities in a neonate. Here, the 
cornea is clear. Keratoglobus is a rare noninflammatory, familial disorder marked by generalised thinning and 
globular protrusion of the cornea. It can be congenital or acquired. The thinning is usually 
greatest at corneal periphery or midperiphery. It can cause refractive errors, otherwise, cornea is 
clear, normal angle of anterior chamber, normal intraocular pressure with no optic disc cupping. Intrastromal ring segments and cross-linking can be used for management. Other options: Option B: Birth injuries resulting in Descemet's membrane tears can also cause corneal opacities. Option C: Peter's anomaly, also known as iridocorneal adhesions or keratolenticular adhesions, is 
a posterior corneal defect with an overlying stromal opacity. Option D: Sclerocornea is a congenital disorder in which the cornea is opaque and resembles the 
sclera, making the limbus indistinct. The central cornea is clearer than the periphery.

questions.question: Question 5: What causes neurotrophic keratopathy?
questions.explanation:
Neurotrophic keratopathy is caused by trigeminal nerve palsy. 169 
Sold by @itachibot Lesions of the fifth cranial nerve from the trigeminal nucleus to the cornea may lead to 
abnormalities of the normal corneal sensation and trophic stimulation. Causes: • Varicella-zoster (most common cause) • Herpes simplex keratitis • Trauma • Irradiation to the eye • Aneurysm/stroke • Multiple sclerosis Mackie characterized three stages of neurotrophic keratitis. • Stage I is characterized by an irregular corneal surface, which later develops into an easily 
recognized punctate keratitis. • Stage II is characterized by a frank epithelial defect, which is typically associated with mild 
anterior stromal oedema and inflammation. • Stage III involves stromal melting and occasionally perforation.

questions.question: Question 6: Paralysis of which of the following nerves is responsible for exposure keratopathy?
questions.explanation:
Exposure keratopathy is caused by paralysis of the facial nerve. It is the result of incomplete lid closure (lagophthalmos) resulting in drying of the cornea (despite 
normal tear production). Causes: • Neuroparalytic, e.g., facial nerve palsy • Reduced muscle tone as in parkinsonism • Mechanical such as lid scarring • Proptosis Note: Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to loss of trigeminal nerve innervation resulting in partial 
or complete loss of sensation.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Erythromycin is least likely associated with cornea verticillata/vortex keratopathy, a whorl-like 
opacity in corneal epithelium, as shown in the image above. Vortex keratopathy occurs due to corneal deposits in the basal epithelium. They are almost always 
bilateral and are readily recognisable by their distinct appearance as fine, golden-brown or grey 
opacities that branch out from a central whorl, usually across the inferior cornea. Opacity due to 170 
Sold by @itachibot drugs is reversible upon stopping the drug. Causes: • Amiodarone (most common) (Option A) • Tamoxifen (Option C) • Indomethacin • Chloroquine (Option D) • Chlorpromazine (rarely) • Fabry’s disease

questions.question:
Question 8: 158 
Sold by @itachibot A 30-year-old albino woman presents with a characteristic finding as shown below. Which of 
the following statements are true regarding the suspected condition?
questions.explanation:
A 30-year-old individual with corneal changes, as shown above, known as gerontoxon or arcus 
lipoides, may require screening for underlying lipid disorder. Arcus senilis (AS), also known as gerontoxon, arcus lipoides or arcus cornealis, is usually an 
age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is 
the most common peripheral corneal opacity, typically benign, occurring bilaterally and prevalent 
among the elderly. However, when observed in individuals under 50, termed arcus juvenilis, it may indicate 
underlying lipid disorder and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, warranting lipid profile 
screening. Unilateral cases of arcus senilis may indicate contralateral carotid artery stenosis due 
to decreased ophthalmic blood flow on the ipsilateral side, resulting in protection from forming 
arcus in the ipsilateral eye. The condition results from the leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal 
capillaries into the corneal stroma, initiating deposition at the superior and inferior cornea. Over 
time, the ring progresses circumferentially, sparing a clear corneal zone adjacent to the limbus 
called the interval of Vogt. The following opacities and rings can resemble arcus senilis: • Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring: A dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in 
Descemet's membrane, classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, 
cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. • Limbus sign: Caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a "milky precipitate" at the corneal 
limbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population. • Pseudo-gerontoxon: A greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previously 
inflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS, seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. The image below depicts the Kayser–Fleischer ring and anterior capsule of the crystalline lens 
(Sunflower cataract) seen in Wilson's disease. 171 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A young male labourer presents to the casualty with severe bilateral eye pain that woke him 
from sleep. He reports welding the previous afternoon without a face shield and symptoms of 
photophobia, blurry vision, tearing, and worsening pain in bright light. Examination reveals 
mild conjunctival injection and diffuse punctate epithelial erosions on the cornea. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The described corneal findings, with his classic history of welding less than 12 hours prior to 
presentation, are suggestive of photophthalmia. Photophthalmia is produced due to exposure to short-wavelength ultraviolet (UV-B) rays. The 
cornea absorbs the majority of UV light (especially 311 to 290 nm). It results in desquamation of 
the epithelium leading to multiple painful corneal erosions. Causes of of UV keratitis: The symptoms appear characteristically after a latent period of 4- 5 hours of exposure to 
ultraviolet light. There is intense burning pain, foreign body sensation, and watering of the eyes. 
There may be associated marked photophobia and blepharospasm. On slit-lamp examination, 
corneal epithelium shows a breach in continuity and takes up fluorescein stain. Management comprises cold compresses, lubricant eye drops and bandaging eyes for 24 hours 
with antibiotic eye ointment and cycloplegic. Avoid local surface topical anaesthesia. Crooke’s 
glass is a prophylactic aid consisting of a spectacle lens combined with metallic oxides to absorb 
ultraviolet or infrared rays and should be used by those who are prone to exposure. Note: Photoretinitis and macular burns are often a result of infrared radiation. Artificial causes 
Natural causes Arc weldingFlash from short- 
circuits,Damaged metal halid 
e lampsTanning bedsUV ger 
micidal lamps. Exposure to strong solar radi 
ation at high altitudes especi 
ally on snow-covered terrain 
(snow blindness)Prolonged vi 
ewing of a solar eclipse witho 
ut proper eye protection. 172 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is a method for long-term preservation of cornea? 159 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: Cryopreservation is used for long-term preservation of cornea, up to 1 year.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection following corneal 
transplantation in India?
questions.explanation:
Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of infectious keratitis after corneal 
transplantation in developing countries. Pneumococcus spp. and Staphylococcus aureus have been found to be the most common causes of 
post-corneal transplant infections in developed countries.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following techniques is the gold standard for assessing corneal thickness?
questions.explanation:
The gold standard technique for assessing corneal thickness is ultrasound pachymetry, which 
uses a corneal pachymeter. Measurement of the corneal thickness (pachymetry) indirectly reflects endothelial function. The 
average central corneal thickness is around 0.5 mm, which gradually increases toward the 
periphery to around 0.7 mm. Normally, as a diurnal variation, corneas tend to be slightly thicker 
just after a person awakes in the morning. Other options: Option A: Confocal microscopy is an imaging technique that allows in vivo examination of corneal 
structures at high magnification and resolution. It is used to assess corneal nerve morphology and 
corneal endothelium. Option B: Keratometry measures the anterior corneal curvature and is traditionally performed 
with a manual keratometer, also known as an ophthalmometer. Option D: Corneal topography is used to assess the anterior corneal surface, its shape and 
thickness. The image below shows a corneal pachymeter. 173 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: Your aunt recently shared that it is becoming cumbersome for her to frequently change her 
glasses. You suggested a referral and the rapid change in power was diagnosed to be due to 
keratoconus. The following image shows the results of one of the investigations done on her. 
What is the name of the investigation? 160 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The investigation shown in the image is corneal topography, and it is used for conditions like 
keratoconus, as seen in this clinical scenario. Corneal topography captures the shape of the cornea by projecting concentric rings of light onto 
its anterior surface, forming a Placido disc pattern. the reflected light is analyzed with specialised 
software to create a detailed map of the corneal curvature. Uses: • Detection of corneal ectasia, mainly keratoconus • To measure corneal thickness • Prior to refractive surgery • Sometimes prior to contact lens fitting The image shows a Placido or Keratoscopic disc which is used for corneal surface assessment. 174 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 20-year-old girl with high myopia was referred by the optometrist for further evaluation. 
She has a history of recurrent allergic conjunctivitis and persistent eye rubbing. An image is 
given below. Which of the following statements are true about the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic 
cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a 
cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision. The pathogenesis is not fully known. Several associations have been identified, which include rigid 
contact lens wear, chronic eye rubbing, Down's syndrome, atopic disease, Leber's congenital 
amaurosis, and connective tissue disease. It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic 
signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular 
corneal topography often causes significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool for KCN detection. Whereas keratoplasty, historically has been the mainstay of treatment for keratoconus, it is now 
generally reserved for eyes that are unable to achieve functional vision with other surgical or 
non-surgical modalities and is only considered only as a last resort, in very advanced disease. It is 
the definitive treatment for keratoconus, not the treatment of choice. 175 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a treatment option in advanced keratoconus?
questions.explanation:
Vision correction with spectacles with spherical/toric soft contact lenses is suboptimal and only 
applicable to the early stages of keratoconus, not in the advanced stages. Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory, bilateral corneal ectasia characterized by 
cone-like steepening due to irregular stromal thinning. This leads to a conical corneal protrusion, 
significant vision loss, myopia and irregular astigmatism. The available options for the management of keratoconus are highly dependent on the stage of the 
disease and its progression. If the disease is stabilized (no progression), the emphasis is given to 
correcting the vision. If the disease is progressing, the emphasis is on slowing (arresting) the 
progression. Treatment options in moderate-to-advanced keratoconus: • Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses and vaulting scleral lenses are the mainstays of vision 
treatment for moderate to advanced KCN. Their main advantage is the creation of a tear pool 
between the lens and the cornea, which naturally neutralizes the ocular aberrations associated 
with keratoconus. (Option B and C) • Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are 
implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature to improve vision. • Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating 
keratoplasty (PKP) Corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin (CXL or C3R) and ultraviolet-A rays arrest the 
progression of the disease. (Option D)

questions.question:
Question 16: A 40-year old male with progressive loss of vision in his left eye was diagnosed with 
against-the-rule astigmatism. Examination revealed peripheral corneal thinning, but there 
was no inflammation. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause?
questions.explanation:
176 
Sold by @itachibot The examination in a 40-year-old male revealed peripheral corneal thinning with no 
inflammation, making peripheral ulcerative keratitis, an inflammatory condition, the least likely 
cause. Peripheral ulcerative keratitis is a destructive inflammatory disease involving the peripheral 
cornea. It is associated with signs and symptoms of inflammation. The other options are causes of 
peripheral thinning in a quiet eye. Other options: Options A and B: Terrien's and Pellucid marginal degeneration are noninflammatory corneal 
degenerations. Pellucid degeneration causes bilateral, inferior corneal thinning that leads to 
marked, irregular, against-the-rule astigmatism. Terrien's degeneration usually begins in the 
superior cornea. Option C: Dellen is a localized thinning of the peripheral cornea associated with the drying of a 
focal area. Usually associated with an adjacent elevated lesion (e.g., pinguecula or a large 
subconjunctival haemorrhage) that impairs physiological lubrication.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 47-year-old woman presented with tearing, irritation, and photophobia of the left eye. On 
examination, a paracentral, crescent-shaped corneal melt was noted. Peripheral ulcerative 
keratitis (PUK) was suspected. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Rheumatoid arthritis is commonly associated with peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK). It is also 
the most common cause. PUK is a group of destructive inflammatory diseases involving the peripheral cornea, 
characterized by the sloughing of corneal epithelium and keratolysis (corneal melting). It can lead 
to corneal perforation. The causes can be divided into: • Infectious- bacterial, viral, protozoal, fungal. • Non-infectious- rheumatoid arthritis, Wegener's granulomatosis, SLE, rosacea, psoriasis etc. Ophthalmologic manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis (due to type III and IV hypersensitivity 
reactions): • dry eye • scleritis • stromal keratitis • peripheral ulcerative keratitis • paracentral keratolysis Treatment of PUK includes protection of the surface from drying and exposure; systemic 
corticosteroids and immunomodulatory; use of adjuncts such as amniotic membrane grafts to 
promote healing; and in some situations, tectonic keratoplasty.

questions.question:
Question 18: 162 
Sold by @itachibot A 54-year-old school teacher presented with a chief complaint of pain in the eyes and 
intermittent blurry vision which was worse in the mornings. Generalized corneal haze was 
noted in both eyes but was more significant in the left. Examination findings are given below. 
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with beaten metal appearance on slit lamp and reduced 
endothelial cell density with coalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's 177 
Sold by @itachibot endothelial dystrophy. Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral, slowly progressive, often asymmetric corneal disease. It 
is characterized by deterioration of endothelial cells and development of guttata, which are 
excrescences of Descemet’s membrane (seen on specular or confocal microscopy). Females are 
affected more than males. It is more common in the 4th decade or later. Endothelial layer dysfunction causes loss of corneal deturgescence, and bilateral oedema of the 
stroma, leading to ocular pain, glare, halos, and decreased visual acuity. Patients have a worse 
vision in the morning because of the eyes being closed during the night causing a buildup of 
corneal oedema. Stages of Fuch’s endothelial dystrophy: • Stage 1: Central corneal guttata that spreads peripherally • Stage 2: Corneal oedema - beaten metal-like appearance • Stage 3: Bullous keratopathy • Stage 4: Subepithelial scarring and superficial vascularization Treatment: • Conservative option- topical hypertonic (saline sodium chloride 5% drops or 6% ointment) and 
bandage contact lenses. • The definitive treatment is endothelial keratoplasty: Descemet’s stripping endothelial 
keratoplasty (DSEK/DSAEK) or Descemet membrane Endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK).

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is not true about macular corneal dystrophy?
questions.explanation:
Macular dystrophy does not spare the peripheral cornea. It is the least common corneal dystrophy. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance. Most other 
corneal dystrophies are autosomal dominant. It is associated with mucopolysaccharidoses and is 
characterized by the deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the stroma and staining by Alcian blue. 
It develops in childhood and is progressive, resulting in profound visual impairment in early adult 
life. Clinical examination reveals superficial whitish fleck-like opacities. These opacities extend 
peripherally to the limbus and the deep stroma down to Descemet’s membrane. The intervening 
corneal stroma develops a progressive and diffuse haze. Note: • Most common dystrophy overall- Microcystic/fingerprint/map-dot dystrophy • Most common stromal dystrophy- Lattice dystrophy • Dystrophy with corectopia- Posterior polymorphous dystrophy • Autosomal recessive dystrophy- Macular dystrophy 178 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following stains is used in identifying granular dystrophy of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Masson trichrome stains stromal hyaline deposits in granular dystrophy of the cornea. Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomal 
dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene. Granular corneal dystrophy is characterized by milky, granular, hyaline deposits in the anterior 
stroma, which may coalesce into irregular shapes. The peripheral cornea and the area between the 
opacities/deposits remain clear. Early symptoms may involve light sensitivity, glare, ocular 
discomfort, pain, and watering. As opacification progresses with age, visual acuity decreases. The following image shows numerous irregularly shaped discrete crumb-like corneal opacities of 
Granular dystrophy, which stain bright red with Masson trichrome.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of oil-droplet keratopathy?

options.a: Deposition of lipid in the anterior stroma

questions.explanation:
Oil-droplet keratopathy occurs due to exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays. Climatic droplet keratopathy (CDK), alternatively known as oil droplet keratopathy/spheroidal 
degeneration/Labrador keratopathy, is an acquired corneal degenerative disorder. Clumps of 
variably sized golden-yellow globules accumulate in the superficial corneal stroma and are 
thought to be derived from photochemical degradation of plasma proteins, by UV radiation. The image shows Labrador keratopathy. 179 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option A: Lipid keratopathy involves the accumulation of whitish or yellow fat deposits, mainly 
cholesterol and fatty acids, which begin intracellularly and later move extracellularly due to 
necrosis of corneal stromal cells. It can be primary (rare, in the cornea free of vascularization) or 
secondary (common, in the vascularized cornea). Option C: Exposure keratopathy results from lagophthalmos (incomplete eyelid closure), causing 
corneal dryness despite normal tear production. Causes include neuroparalytic conditions (like 
facial nerve palsy), reduced muscle tone in Parkinsonism, lid scarring, post-blepharoplasty and 
proptosis. Option D: Neurotrophic keratopathy results from loss of trigeminal nerve innervation to the 
cornea, affecting both sensation and healing. This disruption can cause corneal dryness, 
ulceration, exfoliation, and edema. It is commonly linked to conditions such as trigeminal 
ganglion surgical ablation for neuralgia, stroke, diabetes, herpes simplex and herpes zoster 
keratitis.

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following statements regarding intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation is 
false?

options.b: It is used in the management of keratoconus.
options.c: Corneal perforation is a very common complication.
options.d: It is made of polymethyl methacrylate.

questions.explanation:
Corneal perforation may occur but is quite rare in intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation. Salient points on ICRS: • These segments are made of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) and are implanted into the 
mid-peripheral corneal stroma. • These are used in the management of keratoconus and low myopia. • Improvement in visual acuity and refraction after ICRS implantation is accomplished by a 
shortening of collagen lamellae along the arc length of the ring. There is a redistribution of 
corneal stress due to a change in the curvature of the cornea after implantation of the ICRS. • Decreased corneal sensation can be a postoperative complication. 180 
Sold by @itachibot • More than 90% of patients have <1 D change in refraction at 1-year postoperative follow-up. The image shows the intrastromal corneal ring segment.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 29-year-old woman with normal visual acuity undergoes a routine eye exam. Slit-lamp 
examination reveals numerous crumb-like centrally dense deposits in the anterior corneal 
stroma, bilaterally symmetrical, with clear intervening stroma. Which of the following 
statements is likely to be true? 164 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Histopathology specimen will stain positive with alcian blue
options.b: Histopathologic review will reveal amyloid deposits on congo red staining
options.c: Histopathologic review will reveal hyaline deposits on the Masson trichrome stain

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario, with the given image showing multiple breadcrumb-like deposits, is 
suggestive of granular corneal dystrophy, where histopathology reveals hyaline deposits on the 
Masson trichrome stain. Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomal 
dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene. In granular corneal dystrophy, opacities form due to the abnormal accumulation of hyaline 
protein, assuming a discrete granular form and subsequently coalescing into various irregular 
shapes. The cornea between the opacities and the peripheral cornea remains clear. The condition 
is characterised by milky granular hyaline deposits in the anterior stroma. In many patients, no symptoms occur, whereas some patients develop recurrent erosions. In the 
fifth decade or later, some patients develop sufficient visual difficulties to require keratoplasty. 
Treatment is usually keratoplasty for severe visual handicaps. Note: The beaten metal appearance on the slit lamp and reduced endothelial cell density with 
coalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 6-month-old infant is brought with a history of diffuse, ground glass-like corneal haze in 
both eyes. The corneas are thickened with normal diameters and associated nystagmus. 
Which one of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.a: Intraocular pressure (IOP) is likely to be elevated.
options.b: The corneal stroma shows abnormal deposits that stain with amyloid.
options.c: It could be a bilateral choristoma.
options.d: Descemet’s membrane may be thickened due to an abnormal endothelium.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario most likely suggest congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy 
(CHED), where Descemet’s membrane is abnormally thickened. CHED is a rare disorder characterized by focal or diffuse thickening of the Descemet membrane 
and endothelial degeneration. The key features of this condition include corneal thickness, which 181 
Sold by @itachibot is two to three times the normal, normal intraocular pressure (IOP) and normal corneal diameter. 
Associated features are corneal pannus, nystagmus, and esotropia. Treatment usually involves corneal transplantation (lamellar or penetrating keratoplasty) for 
visual rehabilitation. Other options: Option A: As the corneal diameters are normal, and there are no typical symptoms, congenital 
glaucoma is ruled out. Option B: Amyloid deposits in the corneal stroma are seen in Lattice stromal dystrophy. Option C: Choristomas are congenital lesions representing normal tissue(s) in an abnormal 
location. They are the most common epibulbar and orbital tumors in children. It usually arises at 
the limbus of the eye and may include dermoid tissue, lipodermoid or other tissues. Note: The combination of congenital endothelial dystrophy and progressive neural deafness, is 
known as Harboyan syndrome. This disorder must be distinguished from another autosomal 
recessive disorder, congenital endothelial dystrophy, in which deafness does not occur.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following statements is true about Mooren's ulcer?

options.a: Painless superficial ulcer that can perforate
options.b: Associated with autoimmune and rheumatological conditions
options.c: Characterized by a steep, overhanging edge
options.d: Ulcerative process begins centrally and then moves circumferentially

questions.explanation:
Moorens’s ulcer/ulcus roden is characterized by a steep, overhanging edge. It is described as a chronic serpiginous ulcer of the cornea. It is a subtype of peripheral ulcerative 
keratitis (PUK). It is defined as an idiopathic condition without associated systemic or 
rheumatological conditions and hence is a diagnosis of exclusion. The pathophysiology is thought 
to be due to autoimmune. Clinical features include redness, tearing, and photophobia, but pain is typically the outstanding 
feature. The pain often is incapacitating and may well be out of proportion to the inflammation. 
There may also be a complaint of decreased visual acuity, which may be secondary to associated 
iritis or central corneal involvement. Initially, the ulcerative process spreads circumferentially. Later, it moves centrally to involve the 
entire cornea. In contrast to other forms of PUK, the limbus is involved. The end-stage result is 
typically a scarred, vascularized cornea that may be thinned to less than half of its original 
thickness. Treatment involves corticosteroids and excision of a strip of adjacent conjunctiva, which 
eliminates the conjunctival sources of collagenase and proteoglycanase. The image shows a perforated Mooren's ulcer. 182 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 26: Which layer of the cornea is affected in Reis–Buckler dystrophy?
questions.explanation:
The corneal layer involved in Reis–Buckler dystrophy is Bowman’s membrane. Corneal dystrophies are primarily a bilateral, inherited, non-inflammatory condition specific to 
the cornea. Reis–Buckler dystrophy, an autosomal dominant disorder, is an anterior variant of granular 
stromal dystrophy, characterised by the replacement of the Bowman layer with connective tissue 
bands, primarily affecting the Bowman layer and superficial stroma. Several recurrent corneal 
erosions may occur in childhood along with visual impairment. In this condition, there are grey-white, geographic subepithelial opacities (that are most dense 
centrally and increase over time, eventually forming a reticular pattern. Additionally, corneal 
sensation is reduced as the disease progresses. The image below shows Reis–buckler corneal dystrophy on slit-lamp examination: 183
